Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A 1500m Ice Core from South Pole
Award.AbstractNarration:
1142517/Saltzman

This proposal requests support for a project to drill and recover a new ice core from South Pole, Antarctica. The South Pole ice core will be drilled to a depth of 1500 m, providing an environmental record spanning approximately 40 kyrs. This core will be recovered using a new intermediate drill, which is under development by the U.S. Ice Drilling Design and Operations (IDDO) group in collaboration with Danish scientists. This proposal seeks support to provide: 1) scientific management and oversight for the South Pole ice core project, 2) personnel for ice core drilling and core processing, 3) data management, and 3) scientific coordination and communication via scientific workshops. The intellectual merit of the work is that the analysis of stable isotopes, atmospheric gases, and aerosol-borne chemicals in polar ice has provided unique information about the magnitude and timing of changes in climate and climate forcing through time. The international ice core research community has articulated the goal of developing spatial arrays of ice cores across Antarctica and Greenland, allowing the reconstruction of regional patterns of climate variability in order to provide greater insight into the mechanisms driving climate change. The broader impacts of the project include obtaining the South Pole ice core will support a wide range of ice core science projects, which will contribute to the societal need for a basic understanding of climate and the capability to predict climate and ice sheet stability on long time scales. Second, the project will help train the next generation of ice core scientists by providing the opportunity for hands-on field and core processing experience for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. A postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington will be directly supported by this project, and many other young scientists will interact with the project through individual science proposals. Third, the project will result in the development of a new intermediate drill which will become an important resource to US ice core science community. This drill will have a light logistical footprint which will enable a wide range of ice core projects to be carried out that are not currently feasible. Finally, although this project does not request funds for outreach activities, the project will run workshops that will encourage and enable proposals for coordinated outreach activities involving the South Pole ice core science team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for the scientific oversight and management of an ice core drilling project at the South Pole named SPICEcore (spicecore.org). The major activities included: 

1)    Selection of the site where the ice core was drilled.

2)    Planning for the field operations and logistical requirements.

3)    Planning for and participating in processing of the ice core after collection.

4)    Participation in the development and field testing of a new ice core drill.

5)    Providing scientific oversight for the recovery, logging, and shipment of the ice core over the course of three field seasons.

6)    Facilitating the process of discovery by hosting annual project workshops to bring together ice core scientists from a variety of U.S. institutions.

7)    Facilitating data sharing and training of early career scientists.

8)    Public outreach.

The new South Pole ice core - named SPC14 - was drilled over two Antarctic summer field seasons (10-12 weeks) and reached a final depth of 1751 m, exceeding the originally proposed goal of 1500 m without requiring extra time or additional field resources. An additional third field season was required to pack and ship the ice core back to U.S. The drilling was conducted with a new ice core drill, which was developed for this project. At 1751 m depth, the ice is dated back to about 54,000 years before present.

All the ice has been sent back to the NSF Ice Core Facility located in Colorado, the initial sampling of it has been completed, and the remaining ice has been logged into the U.S. ice core archive. The project left a substantial archive of ice for future investigations. The ice and the new ice core drill will be available to all U.S. researchers for future measurements and drilling projects.  

Sixteen different investigators from thirteen different U.S institutions participated in the logging, processing, and sampling activities organized at the NSF Ice Core Facility over the course of 2 summer months for 3 consecutive years. More than 10,000 samples have been cut and sent to the laboratories of the 16 investigators. Measurements conducted in these laboratories include measurements of various chemical and physical properties of the ice and the air entrapped in the ice. When measurements are completed, the results will provide records of the climate history from a unique area of East Antarctica as well as unique, one of a kind records of the past atmospheric composition.

The South Pole ice core is the highest resolution core from East Antarctica that extends into the last glacial period going back more 54,000 years before present. The South Pole location is particularly important because it is influenced by weather systems that cross the West Antarctic ice sheet. The South Pole ice core records is expected to provide constraints on the stability of the West Antarctic ice sheet over time; West Antarctic Ice Sheet is currently losing mass and contributing to sea level rise. The South Pole ice core has also enabled novel measurements of rare atmospheric gases at high-resolution, made feasible by the very cold temperatures, low impurity levels, and the relatively high accumulation rate at the South Pole. These measurements will provide previously unavailable information on past changes in atmospheric composition and chemistry, and will help identify the reasons why such changes occur. 

This project facilitated development of early career scientists, by providing unique polar field work experience opportunities to young researchers and graduate students. The project also facilitated opportunities for undergraduate education at the laboratories involved in the SPC14 measurements. When the all funded projects that worked on SPICEcore ice are considered, it is estimated that sixty-seven undergraduate students, twenty-six graduate students, and ten post-docs have been directly involved in the SPICEcore project to date.

The project so far has resulted in eight peer reviewed publications. Two additional publications are currently in review and many other papers are in preparation or are anticipated to be written in the near future. Multiple outreach activities were undertaken for the duration of the project, with several articles in print, published videos, and educational webinar presentations.
